natural solution: We can measure $|f(x)-g(x)|$ as the vertical distance between the two graphs at $x$. The sign of $f(x)-g(x)$ is positive if $f(x)>g(x)$, so we focus on the part of the graph where the dashed orange line lies above the solid dark green line.
Within this part of the graph, the greatest vertical distance between the orange and green lines is $\boxed{4}$ (achieved for all $x$ from $8$ to $12$).

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 then x + 2
                      else if 6 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 8
                      else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 12 then x + 2
                      else if 12 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then 10
                      else undefined)"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. g x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 then x + 10
                      else if 2 < x \<and> x \<le> 8 then -x + 14
                      else if 8 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 4
                      else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then x + 2
                      else undefined)"
shows  "Max {f x - g x | x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Below are the graphs of two functions, $f(x)$ and $g(x)$, defined on the domain $0\le x\le 18$:

[asy]
import graph; size(8cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=-1.5,xmax=18.5,ymin=-1.5,ymax=12.5;

pen cqcqcq=rgb(0.75,0.75,0.75);

/*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+cqcqcq+linetype("2 2"); real gx=1,gy=1;
for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);

Label laxis; laxis.p=fontsize(10);

xaxis("",xmin,xmax,Ticks(laxis,Step=2.0,Size=2,NoZero),Arrows(6),above=true); yaxis("",ymin,ymax,Ticks(laxis,Step=2.0,Size=2,NoZero),Arrows(6),above=true);
draw((0,10)--(2,10)--(8,4)--(10,4)--(18,12),darkgreen+1.5);
draw((0,2)--(6,8)--(10,8)--(12,10)--(18,10),orange+dashed+1.5);
[/asy]

If the graph of $f(x)$ is the dashed orange line, and the graph of $g(x)$ is the solid green line, what is the largest value of $f(x)-g(x)$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 We can measure $|f(x)-g(x)|$ as the vertical distance between the two graphs at $x$. The sign of $f(x)-g(x)$ is positive if $f(x)>g(x)$, so we focus on the part of the graph where the dashed orange line lies above the solid dark green line.
 Within this part of the graph, the greatest vertical distance between the orange and green lines is $\boxed{4}$ (achieved for all $x$ from $8$ to $12$).
 *)

theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 then x + 2
                      else if 6 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 8
                      else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 12 then x + 2
                      else if 12 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then 10
                      else undefined)"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. g x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 then x + 10
                      else if 2 < x \<and> x \<le> 8 then -x + 14
                      else if 8 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 4
                      else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then x + 2
                      else undefined)"
shows  "Max {f x - g x | x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Consider two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ defined for $0 \leq x \leq 18$ as follows:

$$
f(x) = 
\begin{cases}
x + 2, & 0 \leq x \leq 6 \\
8, & 6 < x \leq 10 \\
x + 2, & 10 < x \leq 12 \\
10, & 12 < x \leq 18
\end{cases}
$$

$$
g(x) = 
\begin{cases}
x + 10, & 0 \leq x \leq 2 \\
-x + 14, & 2 < x \leq 8 \\
4, & 8 < x \leq 10 \\
x + 2, & 10 < x \leq 18
\end{cases}
$$

Find the maximum value of $f(x) - g(x)$ for $0 \leq x \leq 18$. The final answer is 4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. f x = (if x \<le> 6 then x + 2 else if x \<le> 10 then 8 else 10 + (x - 12))"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. g x = (if x \<le> 2 then x + 10 else if x \<le> 8 then -x + 14 else if x \<le> 10 then 4 else x + 8)"
shows  "Max {f x - g x | x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
a_1.informal problem: Let $f(x)$ be a piecewise function defined as follows: $f(x) = x + 2$ if $0 \le x \le 6$, $f(x) = 8$ if $6 < x \le 10$, and $f(x) = 10 + (x - 12)$ if $10 < x \le 18$. Let $g(x)$ be another piecewise function defined as follows: $g(x) = x + 10$ if $0 \le x \le 2$, $g(x) = -x + 14$ if $2 < x \le 8$, $g(x) = 4$ if $8 < x \le 10$, and $g(x) = x + 8$ if $10 < x \le 18$. Find the maximum value of $f(x) - g(x)$ for $0 \le x \le 18$. The final answer is $4$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and domain :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "domain = {x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18}"
and h1 : "isCont f x"
and h2 : "isCont g x"
and h3 : "continuous_on domain f"
and h4 : "continuous_on domain g"
shows  "Max {f x - g x |x. x \<in> domain} = 4"
a_2.informal problem: Given two continuous functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ on the domain $[0, 18]$, find the maximum difference between the two functions, i.e., $\max_{x \in [0, 18]} (f(x) - g(x))$. The final answer is $4$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 then x + 2 else if 6 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 8 else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then x + 2 else 0)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = (if 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 then 10 else if 2 < x \<and> x \<le> 8 then 14 - x else if 8 < x \<and> x \<le> 10 then 4 else if 10 < x \<and> x \<le> 18 then x + 2 else 0)"
shows  "Max {f x - g x |x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
a_3.informal problem:
Find the maximum difference between two functions, $f(x)$ and $g(x)$, on the interval $0 \le x \le 18$. The functions are defined as follows:

1. For $f(x)$:
   - If $0 \le x \le 6$, then $f(x) = x + 2$.
   - If $6 < x \le 10$, then $f(x) = 8$.
   - If $10 < x \le 18$, then $f(x) = x + 2$.

2. For $g(x)$:
   - If $0 \le x \le 2$, then $g(x) = 10$.
   - If $2 < x \le 8$, then $g(x) = 14 - x$.
   - If $8 < x \le 10$, then $g(x) = 4$.
   - If $10 < x \le 18$, then $g(x) = x + 2$.

The maximum difference between the two functions is 4.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if x \<in> {0..6} then x + 2 else if x \<in> {6..10} then 8 else if x \<in> {10..12} then x + 2 else if x \<in> {12..18} then 10 else 0)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = (if x \<in> {0..2} then 10 else if x \<in> {2..8} then 14 - x else if x \<in> {8..10} then 4 else if x \<in> {10..18} then x + 2 else 0)"
shows  "MAXIMUM {f x - g x | x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
a_4.informal problem:
Find the maximum difference between two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ for $0 \le x \le 18$. The functions are defined as follows:

$f(x) = \begin{cases} 
      x + 2 & \text{for } 0 \le x \le 6 \\
      8 & \text{for } 6 < x \le 10 \\
      x + 2 & \text{for } 10 < x \le 12 \\
      10 & \text{for } 12 < x \le 18
   \end{cases}$

$g(x) = \begin{cases} 
      10 & \text{for } 0 \le x \le 2 \\
      14 - x & \text{for } 2 < x \le 8 \\
      4 & \text{for } 8 < x \le 10 \\
      x + 2 & \text{for } 10 < x \le 18
   \end{cases}$

The maximum difference is $4$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "f x = (if x < 6 then x + 2 else if x < 10 then 8 else 18 - x)"
and h1 : "g x = (if x < 2 then 10 else if x < 8 then 14 - x else if x < 10 then 4 else 2 * x - 16)"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
shows  "Max {f x - g x |x. True} = 4"
a_5.informal problem:
Consider two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ defined as follows: 

- $f(x) = x + 2$ if $x < 6$, $f(x) = 8$ if $x < 10$, and $f(x) = 18 - x$ otherwise.
- $g(x) = 10$ if $x < 2$, $g(x) = 14 - x$ if $x < 8$, $g(x) = 4$ if $x < 10$, and $g(x) = 2x - 16$ otherwise.

Find the maximum value of $f(x) - g(x)$ for $0 \le x \le 18$. The final answer is $4$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (IF x \<le> 6 THEN x + 2 ELSE IF x \<le> 10 THEN 8 ELSE 18 - x + 2)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = (IF x \<le> 2 THEN 10 ELSE IF x \<le> 8 THEN 18 - 2 * x ELSE IF x \<le> 10 THEN 4 ELSE x + 4)"
shows  "Max_on {f x - g x |x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18} = 4"
a_6.informal problem:
Consider two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ defined on the interval $[0, 18]$:

$f(x) =
\begin{cases}
x + 2, & \text{if } x \le 6 \\
8, & \text{if } 6 < x \le 10 \\
18 - x + 2, & \text{if } x > 10
\end{cases}$

$g(x) =
\begin{cases}
10, & \text{if } x \le 2 \\
18 - 2x, & \text{if } 2 < x \le 8 \\
4, & \text{if } 8 < x \le 10 \\
x + 4, & \text{if } x > 10
\end{cases}$

Find the maximum value of $f(x) - g(x)$ for $0 \le x \le 18$. The final answer is 4.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x"
and h1 : "x \<le> 18"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if x < 6 then x + 2 else if x \<le> 10 then 8 else x + 2)"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. g x = (if x < 2 then 10 else if x \<le> 8 then 12 - x else if x \<le> 10 then 4 else x + 6)"
shows  "(GREATEST d. \<exists> x. f x - g x = d) = 4"
a_7.informal problem:
Consider two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ defined as follows:

$f(x) = \begin{cases} x + 2 & \text{if } x < 6 \\ 8 & \text{if } x \le 10 \\ x + 2 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

$g(x) = \begin{cases} 10 & \text{if } x < 2 \\ 12 - x & \text{if } x \le 8 \\ 4 & \text{if } x \le 10 \\ x + 6 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

Find the largest difference between $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ for $x$ in the range $[0, 18]$. The final answer is $4$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "f x = orange_line"
and h2 : "orange_line"
and h3 : "g x = green_line"
and h4 : "green_line"
shows  "MAXIMUM (f x - g x) = 4"
a_8.informal problem: Given two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ representing the orange line and the green line respectively, find the maximum difference between the two functions for $0 \leq x \leq 18$. The final answer is 4.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 18"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if (x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 6) then x + 2 else (if (x > 6 \<and> x \<le> 10) then 8 else (if (x > 10 \<and> x \<le> 18) then x + 2 else 0)))"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. g x = (if (x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 2) then 10 else (if (x > 2 \<and> x \<le> 8) then 12 - x else (if (x > 8 \<and> x \<le> 10) then 4 else (if (x > 10 \<and> x \<le> 18) then x + 8 else 0))))"
shows  "GREATEST a. \<exists> x. (f x - g x) = a = 4"
a_9.informal problem:
Consider two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ defined as follows:

- For $0 \leq x \leq 6$, $f(x) = x + 2$
- For $6 < x \leq 10$, $f(x) = 8$
- For $10 < x \leq 18$, $f(x) = x + 2$

- For $0 \leq x \leq 2$, $g(x) = 10$
- For $2 < x \leq 8$, $g(x) = 12 - x$
- For $8 < x \leq 10$, $g(x) = 4$
- For $10 < x \leq 18$, $g(x) = x + 8$

Find the largest difference between $f(x)$ and $g(x)$. The final answer is $4$.
